fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The minimization operation (sometimes called "unbounded search") is a partial function \mu : ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathsf {Bool} ) \rightharpoonup \mathbb {N} defined as \mu (P) \vcentcolon \equiv \mathsf {search} ( P , 0 ) . where the auxiliary \mathsf {search} function is defined as \mathsf {search} ( P , n ) \vcentcolon \equiv \begin {cases} n & \mathsf {if} \ P(n) \\ \mathsf {search} ( P , n+1 ) & \mathsf {otherwise} \end {cases}
Given a predicate P : \mathbb {N} \to \mathsf {Bool}, \mu (P) will return the smallest n satisfying P, if such an n exists, and will be undefined otherwise.

Let
\langle {-} \rangle denote some computable coding operation \mathsf {List}( \mathbb {N} ) \to \mathbb {N}, and
\mu denote the minimization operator.

Given two functions f, g : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N}, the application of f to g is defined as follows: f \ | \ g \quad \vcentcolon \equiv \quad f( \langle g(0), \ldots , g(r - 1) \rangle ) where r \vcentcolon \equiv \mu r. \ f( \langle g(0), \ldots , g(r - 1) \rangle ) > 0
Defined in Section 3.2.1 of Longley and Normann's book.
